title: People are complaining about premades making them lose, but winning with premades isn't fun either.
body:
Simply being with a large premade is unfun. Being stuck with a majority of your team being non-solo (and the enemy team also likely being in the same situation) means that the solo players have much less impact on the games. Bad premades will feed like there is no tomorrow, BUT good premades will make the other team feed like there's no tomorrow and you are just sitting in lane 2/1/0, a close match in the top lane, and suddenly the game is pretty much over. The score is 30 - 3.

You didn't get to do anything.

ah so, then this highlights an issue with dynamic queue philosophy in combination with the current elo system. there is no way to judge a group's actually elo accurately. the only way is to approximate based off of solo performance, but then when a group can freely pick up, drop, or exchange one or multiple members, there isn't any strong way to keep track of how these changes affects the group's real MMR/ELO. 

in order for Dynamic Queue to be a success in regards to this issue, there would need to be MMR or ELO or similar practices that tracks an individual's contribution to a group.


additionally, something that I strongly feel is that if Riot wants to move towards dynamic Queue, they NEED to implement a voice chat standard, so that they CAN assume all members of the team have the ability to voice chat with the team. because they can't stop players from using third-party voice chat programs, and whether or not voice chat is being used would dramatically affect the team's coordinations and would prevent any good read on MMR/etc

The problem with implementing in-client voice chat is that it would invalidate a lot of their infrastructure aimed at punishing and prevent trolls and ragers. It would be a great gameplay addition, but would also turn league into CoD. 

Personally, I think a better option would be to find ways to allow communication nonverbally (e.g. by a more sophisticated ping system). Won't solve everything, but it would be a good start.

There's always going to be a downside to something, and choosing not to put in the best and most reliable option for communication because "some people will abuse it" is shortsighted at best. That precious ping system people talk about so much can be spammed, and there's no way to prevent a player from doing such because you can't remove their pings. You can mute a mic, and you can mute their text spam, but that ping spam will always be there. Adding even more ping options just crowds and overcomplicates the system, reducing the speed with which you can alert your allies.

An official voice system is the way League needs to go. Unfortunately, they're not going to do it and it's not because "people can abuse it". It's because League has no way currently to police a voice chat system and punish people. The proof is in their doctored data: premades are less toxic, at least according to Riot. Why is that? Because these people are using third-party chat programs and never chatting in-game, so all their toxic behavior is being contained in a system Riot can't see and therefor can't include in their data.

"There's always going to be a downside to something, and choosing not to put in the best and most reliable option for communication because "some people will abuse it" is shortsighted at best. "

No, choosing to ignore all the downsides because you want voice chat is shortsighted. Maybe ignore isn't the right word, but choosing to write them off as "acceptable" is far more shortsighted in my personal opinion.

It would make a few aspects of League better, but make it overall worse.
